ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Critical evaluation and awareness of bias in sources.
I developed an understanding of past economies and their functions and importance for our understanding of our modern economies.

This course was a useful overview of the current methods of inquiry for studying the ancient world, and ancient economic growth in particular. While I did not lear a ton of specific historic material, the course provides a useful overview of methods and philosophies regarding the study of the ancient past, and applies these different methods and perspectives to some historical material.
I learned about ancient economies and how we should study them.
I learned about ancient economic systems and the different schools of thinking regarding their existence and function.

I gained an understanding of the historiography surrounding the study of the ancient economy, as well as learning many specific details related to various ancient economies. I also gain skills related to dealing with literature review and understanding the concept and study of historiography.

While the course may be somewhat deceptively named, make no mistake: this is a course about ancient historiography, not history. Read that last part again. You will not learn about actual ancient economies and how they functioned, which is why I was interested in the course. Instead you will read contemporary economic historians posit theories on how best to study and interpret ancient evidence. 

Truth be told, I think that is a type of class for an audience different from what an audience interested in learning about the actual history of ancient economies. Be weary of that.
I learned about the different perspectives of historians who study the ancient economy.

Learned about different ways and methods to survey ancient economies (Greece, Rome, Babylon etc.). Knowledge of general happenings in historical times however mostly how they relate to economic happenings over history instead of general history.
I learned about the ancient economy.
Insight into the ancient economies if Greece and Roe

I learned a great deal about ancient economies, with great focus being placed on how the leaders of this field viewed it and the field's changes over time. Going in with no information regarding ancient civilizations, this class gives you a great introduction into these societies at large, in addition to their economies. The course also helps you to improve your ability to write for history courses.
yes

I learned to look at our ancient past from a different lens than I had before. I enjoyed looking deeper into different economists and historians perspectives about the specific structure of our ancient economy.

To be frank, I did not learn a lot. The course tended to be overly repetitive and I only came away with a reasonable understanding of the debate about whether the ancient economy was similar to the modern one or not - I cannot say I learned how to answer this.
na
nothing
I learned about what the ancient economy is and what it consists of.
Knowledge on ancient economies and the different discourses surrounding the topic.
I learned about different theories regarding ancient economy. I learned about the importance of disease and climate and agricultural conditions when discussing ancient economies.
Great oversight of the varying schools of thought towards understanding the ancient economy
Learned a lot about the economies of the ancient world and the importance of understanding their impact on modern economies.
Gained knowledge on ancient civilizations and how their economies were thought to function.
I learned the importance of specificity and how complex a topic can be with different points of view.
Great course.
Ideas from a variety of ancient historians like Finley, Polanyi etc. and you get exposure to a broad overview of the different topics and debates in the study of the ancient economy.
I enjoyed this class as I was able to approach the history of economics from a different perspective than when we study modern economics. I learned a lot and thought this class was very interesting.

I learned a lot about the historiography of the ancient world. It is very focused on intellectual history, with less focus than one might expect (I know I was surprised!) on actual in-depth dives into the everyday economic workings of ancient societies.

I learned a lot about ancient economies, as well as how to approach ancient history given the challenges of studying the distant past. I also learned about some of the current scholarly debates in the field.
I learned a surprising amount about the historians that have made up the field of the ancient economy along with a view of the field as a whole.
Learned about the study of various ancient Graeco-Roman economies. Analyzed the different viewpoints and approaches to studying the ancient economy and formulated arguments over the best approaches.
I learned a lot about the study of ancient economies and how to analyze evidence from that time - not a ton about what the ancient economy actually looked like
Introduction to the study of the ancient economy.
Evaluation of firsthand sources
I learned about the ancient economy and how to write an essay using numerous sources.
I learned how to write a proper history paper using ancient pieces of evidence.
Learned a lot about the ancient economy.
Learnt about the ancient economy
A broad understanding of the ancient economy

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Great HU gut, just 3 essays that are all pretty doable.
Strengths, I feel that this course material is very interesting, however the reading load was a bit much at times, so much so I could not keep up.
The strengths are that some of the material is interesting. I think the weaknesses are that the lectures can feel quite repetitive at times.
The course is relaxed which I enjoy, but pretty disorganized. More structured class time and a lay out of where the semester is going would have been helpful.
Very interesting concepts discussed. A lot of writing for a course without a writing credit, but if you enjoy history and/or writing, don't let that stop you.

This course was frustrating because it's called Ancient Economy, but one of the main questions throughout the entire course is whether there actually WAS an ancient economy or not. It all felt very abstract for a history course, but then again it is ancient history. The material was interesting, but only if ancient history is your jam.

The main strength of the course is the professors, great deal of passion for the subject, as well as his direct involvement in much of the cutting edge research related to the field. The main weakness of the course is that the syllabus feels somewhat unfocused in terms of order. Simply rearranging and re-organizing the topics covered would add a lot of cohesion to the course.

Strengths: Prof Manning and Joe Morgan as TA are a killer duo. Both are absolutely brilliant, kind lecturers. Go to office hours and engage with them on the material.

Weaknesses: The absolute biggest weakness of this course is the fact that it is not taught as a seminar. That sounds minor, but I cant emphasize to you how much I feel that the course format hindered my learning in this class. Its difficult to explain, but the material in the lecture was basically designed for a smaller seminar type course or to be discussed in sections. The only problem is that this course is a huge lecture and has no sections, so the material was incredibly abstract and difficult to engage with.
The course covers a great deal of interesting topics, but it could be organized in a way that improves engagement.

The strength of the course to some extent is the material, if you enjoy history then you'll enjoy taking the course and learning more about it. The weakness was that at times the level of engagement with the course was low for most students as it felt like you didn't need to follow along, and could just do the readings before each paper and get a decent grade.
The course covered very unique content which was very interesting

Professor Manning's lectures are engaging and interesting. The readings are generally rather doable each week, and the majority of them are quite interesting. There is not a great workload in this course, but you are still able to take out a great deal if you put in the necessary time. The professor and teaching fellow are also major strengths. Both of them were always available to meet to discuss readings, lectures, and essays and offered great insights and advice.
more engaging
I really liked lecture and the professor was great, however didn't receive as much feedback on my papers as I would have liked.

The course should be made less repetitive and the lectures should be far more focused on an individual point. Professor Manning is clearly an expert, but he tends to ramble in lecture and finds it difficult to actually deliver important learning points to the class. There were almost 100 students taking this course, but it is a damning indictment of the class that only 25 or so would regularly come to lecture. The grading is also very harsh, so be warned - this is in no way a gut. Professor Manning will take off a lot of marks on papers for the most simple mistakes in formatting or bibliographies. The readings are also not always explained well and seem somewhat arbitrary. I find it hard to think of a strength, but I suppose that, if you can keep on top of all the information, you do learn a lot about the ancient mindset, which is intriguing.
na
its bad

I think that the course material has the potential to be very interesting. However, rather than focusing on different characteristics of the ancient economy around the world, we focused more on the definition of the ancient economy, which at times felt repetitive.

Very poor organization. No clear syllabus posted with helpful information. Slides and class resources were not aesthetically sound nor engaging with the class. But the workload and the nature of the assignments were helpful in synthesizing what I was learning in class.
Professor Manning is great, and he is very willing to help those students that make the effort to better their writing and understanding of the material
The information is interesting but the slides and lectures are unorganized.
Great all around. Great professor.
The class is great.

Strengths: Offers various approaches and sources that students can use to study economics. 
Weaknesses: requires some moderate knowledge of ancient history, so students unfamiliar with it may find some difficulty. Some readings were quite confusing too.

Strengths: Manning is an excellent professor whose passion for the topic really shines through and makes lectures more interesting. The guest lecturers are also a fun breath of different air, and I thought they added a fair amount of new perspectives to the class. The class is also not especially demanding, which makes it a relatively easy, fun ride and therefore a better course.

Weaknesses: I think the essay-only assessment style is difficult with a course as large as it was this past year (roughly 80-100?). I would have preferred some exams to break up the writing monotony, and feel like it was hard to get very detailed feedback from the professor - which is only to be expected when he is grading so many pages. I also think the endless focus on the historiography, and a lack of providing background on the ancient societies themselves, really holds the course back. While the class has no prerequisites, it is really hard to look at the intellectual history of a topic without knowing any of the actual history yourself! I know this made me uncomfortable as a writer and student trying to do the essays, and wish the class did some quick priming lessons on the absolute basics of Rome, Greece, Egypt economies and THEN went into the historiography of it all.
This course was very interesting and the assignments were well spaced out.

The course lacks direction mostly. There isnt really an organization to be seen; the professor just comes in and talks about something related to the topic. I also felt there was too much emphasis on the historians without delving into the history itself its like a physics class that talks more about Newton than Newtons laws
Lectures are good, Professor Manning is a very interesting person, his office hours are very helpful

I think it is a really interesting class but it doesnt quite match the course description - it was a lot more just a discussion of how to analyze the ancient economy than a class on what happened in the ancient economy.

Strengths: professor is a great lecturer 

Weaknesses: the class is not well organized and there is barely any feedback on assignments
The strength was the free flow of lecture and the instructor. The content is also very interesting.
Great course all around. More syllabus transparency would be nice.
Good lectures

Overall, the course was well structured but the lectures were not well designed and did not align with the readings for the most part. Additionally, the final paper was assigned a week before the reading period which made things stressful.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Great Gut.

I feel this course would be great for those who have particular interest in historical economies and understanding functions and purposes of ancient economies which can be translated to the modern economies today.
yes, the professor is extremely passionate and knowledgeable on the subject.

I would recommend this course to someone if you are looking for a humanities credit with some writing to it. Do not expect to learn a lot of history, but more about different methods and philosophies of historical analysis.
I would if you are looking for a relaxed, enjoyable class. However, I would tell them not to have super high expectations for what they'll learn.
This course was a great way to learn about different aspects of ancient life. I highly recommend this course to anyone interested in history and reading about various theories regarding history.
Probably only if you're interested in the topic. There isn't a ton of work, but the essays are intellectually challenging and you won't enjoy doing them unless you like the topic.
I would recommend this course to anyone who is just as interested in the historiography surrounding the study of the ancient economy as the ancient economy itself.

I would NOT recommend this course if you are, like me, interested in learning about the actual history of ancient economies, how they functioned, and historical examples. That type of person will be highly disappointed in the material which is entirely focused on discussing the historiography behind ancient economies.

However, if you are interested in discussing the theory on how to approach ancient economies, without actually studying ancient economies, then you will enjoy this course. If you are unsure of what this means, I recommend reading some works by Moses Finley, Karl Polanyi, etc and seeing if you enjoy it  because the entirety of the class is spent discussing those two guys.
Yes, I found the course interesting and fulfilling, and Professor Manning is wonderful.

Very very chill class with a super low workload. 3 papers over the course of a term are not bad at all, with each paper handling different topics. I also recommend this class to Econ majors who are looking to learn more economic history and it's quite interesting to see how the ancients had sophisticated knowledge about formal economics without having formal theories or frameworks.
Maybe take this as a humanities credit? The class was really boring but theres only two essays.
Yes, it provided an economic perspective that was unique but not isolated and pieces of it can be seen in economies today

Yes, I would definitely recommend this course to another student. The course gives you the opportunity to learn a great deal without having a great workload. Essays are graded fairly, and you are given ample time to complete them. Professor Manning and Joe Morgan are also two of the best instructors at Yale which elevates this course. It is also nice that you discuss readings in lecture rather than having to attend an extra discussion section each week.
yes
Yes, the workload is not too challenging. Class is easy to follow and engaging. Professor cares about his students a lot. Papers took a lot of time but there aren't that many so it is do-able.

Do not take this course. The material is uninteresting, the readings difficult to understand (but you still have to do them to write your papers), the grading unsympathetic, and the feedback unstructured. I genuinely wanted to like this course - I have a real love for the ancient world and wanted to learn more about it, but in the end, I came away without being enlightened.
na
no, you learn nothing and the essays are graded stupidly
I would recommend this course to a student looking for an easy humanities elective and anyone interested in the course topic.
Yes, this class was a very interesting introduction to the ancient economy
Not really. There are better history courses and I didnt end the class feeling fulfilled intellectually.
Absolutely, the material, essays, and lectures are great and it rewards those who go the extra mile to really learn and understand the material
Yes, Professor Manning was really great.
Yes, as a non econ major i found it very interesting
Yes, a great course and a great professor.
Yes, especially as an econ major this class gives interesting perspectives that we dont encounter in moderb economics. It is also cool to see the NIE in action in this field.
Yes, I initially took this class to fulfill a humanities requirement but was able to find how interesting this class was and I highly enjoyed it.

I would recommend the course if you are genuinely interested in the historiography of economy / political economy of the ancient world. If you are just looking for a gut, this would not be a great course for that if you do not attend lectures or do the reading, you will have no idea what is going on at all. Also, frankly, if you don't find the topic interesting, I would imagine this course would be just a complete slog.

That said, if you do find this topic interesting, the course would be fantastic. Manning is an excellent prof, who really cares about his students and the topic, and he is delighted by anyone who also wants to engage with the topic he is not out to make your life any more difficult than it needs to be, either.
Yes!
The workload was not a ton, meaning you will only learn if you force yourself. I would recommend this to students with that discipline.
Yes I would, interesting subject that is well taught and very manageable

Yes - of course description updated 
Also make second paper due a week before break so there is more time for the final paper
Only if you are willing to put in extra work to understand the material
Yes
Yes, challenging yet interesting and well taught
Yes. It is really interesting.
Yes!
Yes its informative
Good introduction to ancient economics and provides a basis for further study
